questions.text: Identify the following image showing a non-contrast CT image of the brain:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Extradural Hematoma CT shows a large right extradural haematoma . There are widespread cerebral contusions most prominent in the left frontal lobe . There is traumatic subarachnoid blood in the third and lateral ventricles .

Highyeild:

Extradural haematoma is a neurosurgical emergency. It results from the rupture of an artery, vein or venous sinus, in association with a skull fracture. The classical injury is a fracture to the thin squamous temporal bone, with associated damage to the middle meningeal artery. Presentation : Transient loss of consciousness is typical, and the patient may then present in the subsequent lucid interval with a headache but without any neurological deficit. As the haematoma expands, compensation is exhausted with rapid deterioration. There is contralateral hemiparesis, a reduced conscious level and ipsilateral pupillary dilatation , the cardinal signs of brain compression and herniation. Although this ‘talk and die’ pattern of deterioration occurs in only one-third of cases, it is critically important to recognise the potential for rapid avoidable secondary brain injury in patients who present neurologically intact. Diagnosis : On CT, extradural haematomas appear as a lentiform (lens-shaped or biconvex) hyperdense lesion between the skull and the brain, constrained by the adherence of the dura to the skull. A mass effect may be evident, with compression of the surrounding brain and midline shift. Areas of mixed density suggest active bleeding . A skull fracture will usually be evident. Treatment : Open craniectomy for evacuation of the congealed clot and hemostasis generally is indicated for EDH. In some cases, EDH can be caused by bony venous bleeding that is self-limited and may not require surgical intervention. Generally, patients who meet all of the following criteria may be managed conservatively: clot volume <30 cm, maximum thickness <1.5 cm, and GCS score >8 . Prognosis : Prognosis after successful evacuation is better for EDH than subdural hematoma (SDH). EDHs are associated with lower-energy trauma with less resultant primary brain injury. Good outcomes may be seen in 85% to 90% of patients, with rapid CT scans and intervention.11 In some cases, EDH can also be caused by dural venous sinus tears that rapidly expand and are typically associated with a high degree of morbidity when treated surgically

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Acute Subdural Hematoma On head CT scan, the clot is bright(Hyperdense) or mixed-density, crescent-shaped (lunate), may have a less distinct border, and does not cross the midline due to the presence of the falx. Most SDHs occur over the cerebral hemispheres, but they may also occur between the hemispheres or layer over the tentorium Option: C. Subarachnoid Hemorrhage Trauma is the commonest cause of subarachnoid haemorrhage and this is managed conservatively Option: D. Chronic Subdural Hematoma A true chronic SDH will be nearly as dark as CSF on CT . Traces of white are often seen due to small, recurrent haemorrhages in the collection. These small bleeds may expand the collection enough to make it symptomatic. This phenomenon is referred to as an acute-on-chronic SDH

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The patient is carefully shifted with support and an X-ray neck is to be done

questions.correct_answer: B. The patient is to be shifted and a CT neck is to be done
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The patient is to be shifted and a CT neck is to be done The above situation tells that the patient presented with a cervical injury. MANAGEMENT: Immediate management consists of stabilization of the cervical region with the help of a neck rigid Philadelphia collar to avoid any kind of further injury. The patient should be laid down on a hard surface and the log roll method should be used for assessing injury at other parts of the body. It is followed by gross spinal cord function assessment by asking the patient To move his fingers Whether he passed urine after the accident. Imaging consists of an X-ray (a portable X-ray machine should be used) Cervical CT (Modality of choice)

questions.text: A 30-Year-old male presented to ER following a head injury. CT was normal with poor GCS. MRI showed multiple small haemorrhages with no midline shift. The probable cause is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Diffuse axonal injury

Highyeild:

It is a form of primary brain injury seen in high-energy accidents that usually renders the patient comatose Cause : Damage to the axons due to rotational acceleration and then de-acceleration. Axons may completely disrupt due to the stretching of axons and then retract forming retraction balls. MRI is the investigation of choice Haemorrhage is classically seen in the corpus callosum and dorsolateral midbrain. The prognosis is very poor.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. EDH can be seen as a biconvex lens shape collection of blood above the dura-mater and periosteum. EDH presents with the characteristic lucid interval. Option: B. SDH can be seen as a crescent-shaped collection of blood. It is seen between the dura-mater and the arachnoid membrane. The typical presentation includes a thunderclap headache. Meningitis develops over hours. It occurs due to the tearing of bridging veins. Option: C. IVH can be seen as a hyperdense collection of blood in the brain ventricles.

questions.text: Concavo-Convex shaped Haemorrhage in non-Contrast CT suggestive of
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Subdural hematoma Concavo-Convex shape- SDH.

Highyeild:

Acute Subdural Haematoma Type I High-energy injury mechanisms can result in the rupture of cortical surface vessels with significant associated primary brain injury. This results in an expanding haematoma with rapid deterioration and development of signs of raised ICP reminiscent of extradural haematoma, without the lucid interval. These collections require prompt evacuation, typically by craniotomy or craniectomy. Type II : Older and often anticoagulated, a lower energy injury leads to venous bleeding around the brain. Depending on the total volume of bleeding, the resulting haematoma may present early as acute subdural haematoma, after delay and osmotic expansion as chronic subdural haematoma or may even remain clinically silent. Type III : Present much later with a further ‘acute-onchronic’ subdural haematoma. On diagnosis, the clotting function should be corrected wherever possible. Bleeds of significant size, with significantly associated midline shift or with deteriorating neurology, require urgent evacuation. Smaller bleeds in neurologically stable patients may be managed conservatively , at least initially: liquefaction of the clot over 7–10 days after the bleed may allow for a much less invasive evacuation through burr holes. Since the dura is not as adherent to the brain as it is to the skull, subdural blood is free to expand across the brain surface, giving a diffuse concave appearance. Chronic Subdural Hematoma : Common in the elderly, especially those on anticoagulants Clinical deficits result from the osmotic expansion of a degrading clot over days/weeks Diffuse hypodense lesion on CT Burr hole drainage is usually preferred

questions.text: First reflex to return after Spinal Shock resolves?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bulbo-cavernous reflex Spinal shock is a temporary physiological disorganisation of spinal cord function that starts within minutes following the injury. The length of effect is variable, but it can last 6 weeks or longer. It is characterised by Paralysis, Decreased tone and Hyporeflexia. Once it has resolved the Bulbo-cavernous reflex returns. Bulbo-cavernous reflex can be elicited in females by traction on the Foley catheter.

Highyeild:

Focused abdominal sonography for trauma and extended FAST (FAST and eFAST) Focused abdominal sonography for trauma (FAST) is a technique whereby ultrasound (sonography) imaging is used to assess the torso for the presence of free fluid in the abdominal cavity and is extended into the thoracic cavities and pericardium (eFAST). There should be no attempt to determine the nature or extent of the specific injury. eFAST is usually a rapid, reproducible, portable and non-invasive bedside test and can be performed at the same time as resuscitation. eFAST is accurate at detecting >100 mL of free blood ; however, it is very operator dependent and, especially if the patient is very obese or the bowel is full of gas, it may be unreliable. Hollow viscus injury and solid organ injury are difficult to diagnose , even in experienced hands, as small amounts of gas or fluid are difficult to assess and eFAST has a low sensitivity (29–35%) for organ injury without hemoperitoneum . eFAST is also unreliable for excluding injury in penetrating trauma . If there is doubt, the eFAST examination can be repeated.

questions.text: A patient reported with fall from a height and the people nearby admitted him to the hospital. On examination, he was conscious and was crying out loud in pain. The paramedics reached after half an hour after reporting the patient to the hospital. On examination, you found out that the BP is 100/60 mm hg, PR 104/min, RR -38/min, temp- 99.2 F, and GCS- 3/15. Diminished breath sounds on rt side of the chest. chest X-ray was done and revealed right-sided pneumothorax with 1 – 7 ribs fracture on the left side. X-ray legs showed both bones fracture in both legs. For transfusion in the patient, what would be the ratio of transfusion products that will be given to the above-mentioned patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1:1:1 The patient needs to be managed according to the ATLS protocol. Prevention of dilutional coagulopathy is central to the damage control resuscitation of patients who are actively bleeding. This is the prime reason for delivering balanced transfusion regimes that deliver a resuscitation which approximates that of whole blood. In most practices, this means delivering matched units of red blood cells, plasma and platelets in a 1:1:1 ratio. Crystalloids and colloids should be avoided if at all possible.

Highyeild:

AIRWAY WITH CERVICAL SPINE PROTECTION: Assess airway patency : If not patent : Chin lift/jaw thrust Clear airway from foreign body Insert oropharyngeal/nasopharyngeal airway Establish a definitive airway. BREATHING ( VENTILATION AND OXYGENATION ): Assess breathing, Rate and depth Percuss chest Auscultate chest Administer oxygen Attach pulse oximeter for monitoring the spo2 of the patient. If abnormal breathing is detected, management: Ventilate the patient if required. Alleviate tension pneumothorax Seal open pneumothorax. CIRCULATION WITH HEMORRHAGIC CONTROL: Assess circulation, Identify external haemorrhage Pulse BP Skin colour Identify potential internal haemorrhage. If the abnormality is detected: Apply direct pressure over the external bleeding point. Insert 2 large bore iv canula. Simultaneously obtain blood for blood transfusion and cross match Initiate iv fluids. Consider the potential need for operative management. DISABILITY : Assess consciousness Use GCS score. Assess pupils Size/ equality/ reaction. EXPOSURE / ENVIRONMENT: Completely undress the patient but prevent hypothermia. Anterior and posterior nasal packing should be done to prevent nasal bleeding. Resuscitation of patients with hypovolemic shock begins by making the airway secure by ensuring proper ventilation and oxygen therapy. External bleeding is done by the application of pressure and surgical control. Immediately life-threatening pulmonary injuries should be early detected and treated as soon as possible. Large bore iv canula to prevent hypovolemic shock The chest X-ray is of utmost importance in cases with pulmonary injuries. Trauma resuscitation (1:1:1) packed cells, plasma, and platelets are used in this ratio. Because most patients do not require more than 6 units of PRBCs, most do not receive FFP. For patients who require more units of PRBCs, 7-12 units of PRBCs should be administered along with 6 units of FFP and 1 unit of apheresis platelets. Preferably, FFP and platelets should be transfused first, before the next 6 units of PRBCs are transfused.

options.label: B

questions.correct_answer: B. The patient should not be shifted and a portable X-ray should be performed
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The patient should not be shifted and a portable X-ray should be performed

Highyeild:

In trauma patients, cervical immobilisation is the first step in management along with the airway. Hence, imaging should be done after hard neck collar support and a long spine board. In fact, a cross-table lateral cervical spine X-ray is considered, in the same trolley itself without shifting the patient. A surgeon should accompany the patient if needed so that the patient can be transferred immediately to OR if any hemodynamic instability happens. Simultaneously all patients with blunt trauma require cervical spine immobilisation until the injury is excluded. This is typically accomplished by applying a hard collar or placing sandbags on both sides of the neck with the patient’s forehead taped across the bags to the backboard. Soft collars do not effectively immobilize the cervical spine. for penetrating neck wounds, however, cervical collars are not believed useful because they provide no benefit, but may interfere with assessment and treatment.

questions.text: A- 42 year- old man, was intubated after traumatic brain injury for decreasing GCS. Currently, he opens his eyes to pressure and intubated and withdraws his left arm which led to pain. What will be the GCS score?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

6 It is no longer recommended to assign 1 point to non–testable elements, therefore a combined score should not be used here as it would imply that the patient is more unwell than they really were .

Highyeild:

Glasgow Coma Scale Score : The initial assessment of the trauma patient includes the primary survey, resuscitation, secondary survey, and definitive care. Neurosurgical evaluation begins during the primary survey with the determination of the GCS score (usually referred to simply as the GCS) for the patient. The GCS is determined by adding the scores of the best responses of the patient in each of the three categories. The motor score ranges from 1 to 6, verbal from 1 to 5, and eyes from 1 to 4. The GCS, therefore, ranges from 3 to 15 Tracheal intubation or severe facial or eye swelling can impede verbal and eye responses. In these circumstances, the patient is given a score of 1 with a modifier, such as verbal “1T” where T = tube

questions.text: Most surgically accessible Zone in case of Neck Injuries
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Zone II

Highyeild:

Zone-I extends from the thoracic inlet to the cricoid cartilage and contains large vascular structures as well as the trachea and esophagus. Stretching from the cricoid cartilage to the angle of the mandible, Zone-II is the most accessible surgically and contains the carotid and vertebral arteries, jugular veins, and structures of the aerodigestive tract . Zone-III includes the neck between the angle of the mandible and the base of the skull . Structures within zone III include blood vessels that are difficult to expose surgically . Although zone II injuries with the physical exam are indicators for the depth of injury (i.e., violation of platysma) traditionally mandated operative exploration, it has since been recognized that only those patients with hard signs of vascular or aerodigestive injury require immediate operation while the remainder may undergo radiographic assessment (so-called “no-zone” approach)
